issues.title: Requirement for "scim" scope in access token
issues.author: Zollnerd
issues.body:
https://github.com/jischr/scim-ipsie-profiles/blob/c289a468cd17d84b1878d9c33494e8c58e1559cb/draft-schreiber-ipsie-scim-al1-profile.md#L112

OAuth doesn't define scope names, which leads to a few thoughts:

1. Should this requirement be changed to say something to the effect of "must contain scopes that don't grant permission for actions outside of the SCIM service provider"? 

2. As part of SCIM-related work in IPSIE, should we try to define specific scopes or a framework for designing scopes that would scale beyond users and groups?

3. "scim" is still pretty broad, versus something like scim.groups.read or scim.users.readwrite - definitely feels more granular than a lot of implementations have today, but if we've got a chance to raise the bar, this sort of approach might be worth including.

issues.title: IPSIE "roles" vs SCIM "groups" statement incorrect
issues.author: Zollnerd
issues.body:
https://github.com/jischr/scim-ipsie-profiles/blob/c289a468cd17d84b1878d9c33494e8c58e1559cb/draft-schreiber-ipsie-scim-al1-profile.md#L197-L198

SCIM has three distinct concepts currently - Groups, which are a resource type alongside Users, as well as attributes on the User resource "roles" and "entitlements". There are SCIM-enabled applications that support the user.roles attribute and do not support the group resource type. 

We probably need to figure out what the actual protocol-agnostic requirement is and then map it into SCIM requirements.

issues.title: Does AL1 need a requirement to support groups?
issues.author: Zollnerd
issues.body:
https://github.com/jischr/scim-ipsie-profiles/blob/c289a468cd17d84b1878d9c33494e8c58e1559cb/draft-schreiber-ipsie-scim-al1-profile.md?plain=1#L239

Probably related to https://github.com/jischr/scim-ipsie-profiles/issues/4

Not all apps have a need to support groups. If they support something like "roles" or "entitlements" then that provides another way for the IDP to view and manage access in the app. Groups have a downside for entitlement granting into apps as well, as the SCIM group resource created by the client in the app can have any name (displayName is an arbitrary label) and what permissions are assigned to the group (and inherited by its members) is generally not visible to the IDP.

comments.author: jischr
comments.body:
so i think this issue is two fold. 

first, first is aroudn SPs not needing groups. could be resolved with:
- The IdP MUST support Group operations
- The SP MAY support Groups if it aligns with their use case

Second point is clarification of what a group is:
Should the profile distinguish between Groups as organizational units the IdP owns and pushes, versus Application-native roles the IdP can read but doesn't manage?

comments.author: Zollnerd
comments.body:
> Should the profile distinguish between Groups as organizational units the IdP owns and pushes, versus Application-native roles the IdP can read but doesn't manage?

SCIM has both of these concepts with the same names that you used here, and both are regularly in use with current SCIM implementations, so I think we should address both of them separately. I'm in favor of referring to them using the existing SCIM terminology, and if necessary, we can add items to the terminology section near the beginning of the document.

> first, first is aroudn SPs not needing groups. could be resolved with:
> 

- > The IdP MUST support Group operations

- > The SP MAY support Groups if it aligns with their use case

I think the second option is the correct one. Virtually everything in SCIM is optional when it comes to the schema and what resources are supported, and not all applications have need for groups and/or roles. There's an argument that having some way for the IDP to see and/or manage entitlement grants in the application improves security posture. If I were to try to write a SCIM AL* requirement to capture that, it would probably be a requirement for the SP to support at least one of a list of methods that help to achieve that. 

Given the multiple options that are available, IMO we should provide requirements that apply if the application supports one of those features. I'm not sure if we should be mandating either of them at AL1, though - would need to think about that more and discuss with a wider group.

issues.title: All "provisioning actions" must be logged - clarify "provisioning actions"
issues.author: Zollnerd
issues.body:
https://github.com/jischr/scim-ipsie-profiles/blob/c289a468cd17d84b1878d9c33494e8c58e1559cb/draft-schreiber-ipsie-scim-al1-profile.md?plain=1#L260

We should clearly define "provisioning actions" - specifically, if it only covers modifications, or if reads are also expected to be logged. I can't think of any SCIM SP/IDP that logs each read request, and I think the definition should be that "provisioning actions" == create/update/delete (modifications) only

issues.title: Explicitly disallow SCIM SPs from supporting the user "password" attribute
issues.author: Zollnerd
issues.body:
https://github.com/jischr/scim-ipsie-profiles/blob/c289a468cd17d84b1878d9c33494e8c58e1559cb/draft-schreiber-ipsie-scim-al1-profile.md?plain=1#L117

Not sure where to put the requirement, but I think we should add one that explicitly disallows SCIM SPs from supporting the user "password" attribute. Federation/SSO should be required, which means that the "password" attribute on the User resource shouldn't be needed. There are legacy apps that may require passwords to be synced into them, but those won't be IPSIE SL* compliant and similarly shouldn't be AL* compliant, IMO. 

I'm not sure if a requirement is needed or useful on the IDP side - the IDP's client/provisioning service will always support a superset of features compared to what any single application may use, and an IDP's SCIM client supporting sending the user "password" attribute doesn't matter if it isn't being used with the SCIM SP. I can think of some possible implementation mistakes that could lead to security issues, such as mapping IDP's user.password to any random attribute on the application's end, and then using that to discover the user's password in the IDP - but my gut is that that isn't in IPSIE's scope.

comments.author: jischr
comments.body:
@Zollnerd - i think this is valid. just a few questions for discussion:

Should the Application reject the entire request if password is included, or only reject the password attribute itself?
For example, if a POST /Users includes password alongside otherwise valid attributes, does the whole create fail, or should the Application create the user and ignore/reject only that attribute?

Does this extend to extension schemas?
An Application could technically accept password-equivalent credential material under a custom schema namespace, and the current language wouldn’t catch that.

Is the intent to prohibit only the core SCIM User.password attribute, or is the intention requirement broader i.e., prohibiting any attribute that carries credential material (hashed passwords, MFA seeds, recovery codes, etc.)?

comments.author: Zollnerd
comments.body:
> Should the Application reject the entire request if password is included, or only reject the password attribute itself? 
> For example, if a POST /Users includes password alongside otherwise valid attributes, does the whole create fail, or should the Application create the user and ignore/reject only that attribute?

The object's schema is defined by the application, so the most critical requirement is going to be that the application MUST not support the password attribute. 

RFC 7644 gives pretty broad discretion to the SCIM service provider to alter or ignore parts of incoming requests - both what attributes are included, and their values.  In practice, some service providers will silently drop unsupported attributes on a POST, and others will return an error due to the inclusion of unsupported attributes. 

> Does this extend to extension schemas?
> An Application could technically accept password-equivalent credential material under a custom schema namespace, and the current language wouldn’t catch that.

> Is the intent to prohibit only the core SCIM User.password attribute, or is the intention requirement broader i.e., prohibiting any attribute that carries credential material (hashed passwords, MFA seeds, recovery codes, etc.)?

Good catch. RFC 7643 section 3.3 has a normative requirement related to this:
`_Schema extensions SHOULD avoid redefining any attributes defined in this specification and SHOULD follow conventions defined in this specification._`

That SHOULD is a problem, as is the difference in interpretation that various people may have when it comes to whether or not an extension is redefining attributes defined in RFC 7643.  

When I created this issue, I was thinking only of user.password, but I think there's value in determining what is allowed, and for the things that are allowed, what the rules are.  

I'll add language around user.password to the current edits I'm working on, and I'll create a new issue to track the other scenarios.

issues.title: Add an explicit requirement for IDPs to NOT use PUT to update groups
issues.author: Zollnerd
issues.body:
https://github.com/jischr/scim-ipsie-profiles/blob/c289a468cd17d84b1878d9c33494e8c58e1559cb/draft-schreiber-ipsie-scim-al1-profile.md?plain=1#L185

PUT is sketch enough while updating users, but it's an outrageously bad idea for groups. AL1 already says that PATCH must be supported, but given the SCIM protocol spec says support for PUT is a global requirement for updateable resources, I think an explicit SHALL NOT would be good.

comments.author: jischr
comments.body: yes i'm in support of explicitly adding the shall not. thanks for bringing this one up

issues.title: Require JWT Bearer Assertion + DPoP in future (maybe not at AL1)
issues.author: Zollnerd
issues.body:
https://github.com/jischr/scim-ipsie-profiles/blob/c289a468cd17d84b1878d9c33494e8c58e1559cb/draft-schreiber-ipsie-scim-al1-profile.md?plain=1#L101

Given the amount of power held in tokens used for IAM APIs, if/when https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-parecki-oauth-jwt-dpop-grant/ becomes an RFC I think it should be added to the authn/authz requirements. In an ideal world at AL1, but if not, then AL2. 

If there are any other ways to improve the security around the tokens accessing the SCIM APIs, might be worth adding those to AL1 as well, especially if they're already an RFC and are easier to implement than DPoP.

comments.author: jischr
comments.body: this one grants more discussion, maybe with the broader group

issues.title: Requirement for IDP to deactivate within X minutes
issues.author: Zollnerd
issues.body:
https://github.com/jischr/scim-ipsie-profiles/blob/c289a468cd17d84b1878d9c33494e8c58e1559cb/draft-schreiber-ipsie-scim-al1-profile.md?plain=1#L140

I'm not sure how practical this requirement is at 5 minutes. SCIM APIs usually have request rate limits that lead to SCIM clients building an outgoing message queue to avoid triggering 429 responses from the SCIM API. These queues usually operate on a FIFO (first in, first out) model, although inserting specific requests to the top of the queue is possible. For larger source directories with hundreds of thousands of users, the churn in the directory combined with any "transient" deactivations that may have the user go from active -> disabled -> active in the span of a few minutes could end up with the active true/false changes consuming most or all of the SCIM API's request rate allowance, keeping other changes stuck in that outgoing message queue for a while. 

An example of the transient deactivation I mentioned above is: the user signs in from new location, a risk event triggers that leads them to lose access to some apps/have sign-in at the IDP blocked/etc., and then they mitigate the "high risk" flag via something like strong MFA.

Any requirement on the AL* side should probably take the existence/use of other mechanisms to disable an account (CAEP?, OpenID Provider Commands..) since if another mechanism that can accomplish the same thing is in use requiring it with SCIM AL1 may not have any benefit, but it will increase COGS for both the SCIM client and SCIM service provider, as well as consuming the SCIM client's request allowance with the SCIM service provider.

comments.author: jischr
comments.body:
100% agreed this shouldnt be a requirement. lets remove the time window. 
debating if its even worth it to specify "urgency"... thoughts?

issues.title: OAuth requirements unclear
issues.author: Zollnerd
issues.body:
https://github.com/jischr/scim-ipsie-profiles/blob/c289a468cd17d84b1878d9c33494e8c58e1559cb/draft-schreiber-ipsie-scim-al1-profile.md?plain=1#L93-106

Feedback from Aaron last week (Feb 10th, 2026) in the IPSIE WG call was that the quoted OAuth requirements aren't clear enough. 

I support requiring _something_ backed by signed JWTs from the IDaaS/IDP, but should that be:

1. client_credentials grant with the JWT provided as the "client_assertion" param
2. urn:ietf:params:oauth:grant-type:jwt-bearer grant with the JWT as the "assertion" param
3. something else?

issues.title: Caveats to "must allow reactivation of a deactivated user" requirement
issues.author: Zollnerd
issues.body:
https://github.com/jischr/scim-ipsie-profiles/blob/c289a468cd17d84b1878d9c33494e8c58e1559cb/draft-schreiber-ipsie-scim-al1-profile.md?plain=1#L153

We should add wording to permit an application to only allow reactivation of a disabled user if certain app-specific conditions are met such as licenses being available, security risk events being addressed, etc.

comments.body: do we want to reject the password attribute? ie return a 400?
this may want to become a stricter requirement in the future.
As it is that requirement says they MUST support a pagination method. What are you thinking for making it stricter?
That depends on the implementation and the HTTP method being used. The SCIM spec gives more leeway to silently ignoring things it doesn't like in a POST, but a PATCH would have to return a 400, IIRC.
